Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: From Impact to Impulsive Manipulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
When people work, they often take advantage of impacts between objects, for example, a worker impacts a nail with a hammer to drive it in. These impacts generate what are known as "impulsive forces" to do work. People take advantage of smaller impulsive forces to complete many common daily tasks too; inserting a key into a key hole, opening a stuck window, and cracking an egg. While the impacts between a plate and a table is much lighter than that applied to a nail, it is nonetheless just as useful. Today's robots have not been designed to take advantage of impulsive forces to accomplish tasks. The PI conducts an investigation into several fundamental and experimental issues surrounding impulsive robotic manipulation and develops methods for their use in robot control. Project results are advancing the theory of multi-body impacts and widening the capabilities of robots. Direct applications of the results are leading to faster and more agile robots for civil and military services and improved efficiency of industrial processes.

The technical goal of this project is to gain in-depth understanding about control of collision outcomes and, more importantly, integration of impact planning with motion planning in robot manipulation. The project consists of three phases. The first phase advances the Principal Investigator's recent work on compliant and multiple impacts to modeling of n-body simultaneous collisions, tackling issues that include state space condensation, impulse growth in high-dimensional space, sensitivity to physical parameters, and area and nonlinear contacts. In parallel with the analysis is the development of a graphical interface called MultiCollide for interactive collision simulation. The second phase investigates how a manipulator can impart via impact a desired motion to an object, solving an inverse impact problem that connects impact dynamics with trajectory planning and manipulator dynamics. The final phase focuses on two impulsive manipulation tasks that respectively address the following important issues: how to leverage contact compliance and geometry, and how to interleave impact planning with robot motion planning.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Impact is a phenomenon that takes place in our daily life.  We leverage the large force generated by impact to perform everyday tasks that would be otherwise very difficult.  Examples include hammering a nail, cracking an egg, and opening a stuck window.  In a ball sport, impact is more skillfully used by a human player, whether to do a banana kick in soccer, to make a powerful spike in volleyball, or to hit a fast serve in tennis.  Today's robots have not been able to take advantage of impulsive forces to accomplish tasks.

The goal of this project is to computationally model impact, and then apply the modeling result to program a robotic arm to demonstrate skillful maneuvers that can match the level of human dexterity.  We have studied collisions involving two and multiple rigid bodies, solving several open problems with analyses that are based on accumulation of impulse and transformations between kinetic and potential energies during impact.

We have developed a system that controls a robotic arm from Barrett Technologies, Inc. to bat an object in free flight to a target location.   This highly skillful move challenges the robot's sensing, planning, and action to the extent of coordination in just a fraction of one second.   To achieve the task, we have designed a method that employs two high speed cameras to accurately estimate the object's motion (spinning included) as it is flying towards the robotic arm, which meanwhile keeps adjusting its movement to reach the best batting position and speed.  In our experiments, the arm has demonstrated a better batting performance on different objects than by a human being with no training.

 


Last Modified: 10/23/2018
Modified by: Yan-Bin Jia

Images (1 of )
  • Whole arm manipulator (WAM) from Barrett Technologies, Inc. bats a dumbbell-like object joining two ping pong balls with a plastic cylinder. The target, a row of three toy bowling pins, is placed at three different locations. YouTube video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dGBevZ54E3s.
    Matthew Gardner, Xiaoqian Mu, and Yan-Bin Jia
    Copyrighted
    Yan-Bin Jia
    WAM Arm batting a "dumbbell" to knock down toy bowling pins
  • WAM Arm bats an incoming ping pong ball onto a hanging plastic board at three different locations.
    Matthew Gardner, Xiaoqian Mu, and Yan-Bin Jia
    Copyrighted
    Yan-Bin Jia
    WAM Arm batting a ping pong ball onto a hanging board
  • WAM Arm bats a cork square into the same net at three locations.
    Matthew Gardner, Xiaoqian Mu, and Yan-Bin Jia
    Copyrighted
    Yan-Bin Jia
    Batting a square into a net
  • Online interactive simulator of a collision between two or multiple rigid bodies. The user can set up a collision scene by choosing objects of various geometry and setting their velocities and angular velocities. Website: http://robotics.cs.iastate.edu/MultiCollide/docs/index.html.
    Jacob Stimes
    Yan-Bin Jia
    MultiCollide: A rigid body impact simulator
  • Estimation of the position, orientation, velocity, and angular velocity of a cuboid during its free flight. Estimated (body) frames are drawn in white: (left) initial frame estimates and (right) better frame estimates after short time periods. Video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o7Zc0ZGgPZ4.
    Matthew Gardner and Yan-Bin Jia
    Copyrighted
    Yan-Bin Jia
    Motion estimation of a flying cuboid
  • Resting configurations of ten balls after three break shots: (a) stop shot, (b) follow shot, and (c) draw shot. The cue ball is coming from the left. Post-shot trajectories as plotted are generated by our engine for modelling multibody impacts.
    Feifei Wang, Huan Lin, and Yan-Bin Jia
    Copyrighted
    Yan-Bin Jia
    Modeling of break shots
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Impact is a phenomenon that takes place in our daily life. We leverage the large force generated by impact to perform everyday tasks that would be otherwise very difficult. Examples include hammering a nail, cracking an egg, and opening a stuck window. In a ball sport, impact is more skillfully used by a human player, whether to do a banana kick in soccer, to make a powerful spike in volleyball, or to hit a fast serve in tennis. Today's robots have not been able to take advantage of impulsive forces to accomplish tasks. The goal of this project is to computationally model impact, and then apply the modeling result to program a robotic arm to demonstrate skillful maneuvers that can match the level of human dexterity. We have studied collisions involving two and multiple rigid bodies, solving several open problems with analyses that are based on accumulation of impulse and transformations between kinetic and potential energies during impact. We have developed a system that controls a robotic arm from Barrett Technologies, Inc. to bat an object in free flight to a target location. This highly skillful move challenges the robot's sensing, planning, and action to the extent of coordination in just a fraction of one second. To achieve the task, we have designed a method that employs two high speed cameras to accurately estimate the object's motion (spinning included) as it is flying towards the robotic arm, which meanwhile keeps adjusting its movement to reach the best batting position and speed. In our experiments, the arm has demonstrated a better batting performance on different objects than by a human being with no training. Last Modified: 10/23/2018 Submitted by: Yan-Bin Jia
